Award.AwardTitle: CPS: Synergy: Information Flow Analysis for Cyber-Physical System Security

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project develops a theory of accountability that encompasses both control and computing systems. A unified theory of accountability in Cyber-Physical Systems (CPS) can be built on a foundation of causal information flow analysis, a well-established set of methods for computer security. Information flow properties model how inputs of a system affect its outputs. Causal information flow notions provide a useful foundation for accountability since they support traceability, that is, not just detection of violations but also responsibility-assignment, which then can be used to adopt corrective measures. The intellectual merit of the proposed project lies in developing a unified foundation for CPS security based on theories of accountability, which build on causal information flow analysis. Broader impacts include the design of resilient and secure CPS, a key to sustaining reliable operation of a wide range of critical infrastructure applications for societal benefit, such as transportation and smart-grid systems.

The project is organized into three major thrusts. With regards to attack detection the project develops information flow analyses to support passive and active detection against realistic adversaries. First, a general framework of information flows to recover existing results related to detection in a unified manner is proposed. Second, information flows are used as an analysis tool, with the goal of producing new results on active detection and stealthy attack characterization. The proposed project will employ this framework to formally study a set of general questions about detection. With respect to responsibility assignment and identification, the project seeks to develop theory and methodologies for identifying nodes responsible for an attack by a novel combination of methods from cryptography and control theory. In particular, it will leverage tools from traitor tracing in cryptography to efficiently search for subsets of nodes that contain malicious or faulty entities. It will employ methods from control theory to evaluate if given subsets of nodes are misbehaving or normal and it will investigate control and design policies to directly attribute information flows to distinct entities. The final task seeks to develop corrective measures via resilient system design and control. This task seeks to develop algorithms to support resilient offline (resource allocation) and online (architectures and algorithms that enable resilient online control) design of CPS and analysis tools to evaluate the security of CPS under composition.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Cyber-Physical Systems (CPSs), engineered systems which apply computing, communication, and control in physical spaces, continue to evolve. CPSs involve devices with widespread sensing, networking, and processing functionalities and are used in applications that require safety, efficiency, and reliability including manufacturing, water distribution, waste management, health care, and the smart grid. Ensuring security is a major challenge in CPSs.

The project contributed to the Science of Cyber-Physical Systems in the area of security, by addressing challenges in secure CPSs design. The aim is to develop a theory of accountability that encompasses both control and computing systems, leveraging a number of existing tools and generalizing them to the CPS framework, so that they can be applied to both the cyber and the physical. A unified theory of accountability in CPSs can be built on a foundation of causal information flow analysis, a well-established set of methods for computer security. The project lives at the intersection of two disciplines: it takes approaches from computer security and significantly augments its scope to include physical dynamical systems, advancing the science of CPS. Information flow properties model how inputs of a system affect its outputs. Causal information flow notions provide a useful foundation for accountability since they support traceability, i.e. not just detection of violations but also responsibility-assignment, which then can be used to adopt corrective measures.

The project has significantly advanced the state of art in the area of detection and identification of attacks on cyber-physical system, by developing a number of tools aimed at countering attacks from powerful adversaries. It developed methods of active detection, able to detect attacks provably stealthy under passive detection schemes, by designing information flows capable of revealing the presence of an attacker. It proposed two approaches for active detection and system authentication: physical watermarking at the control input, and a moving target approach. In Physical Watermarking a known noisy input, or watermark, is injected into the CPS. It is expected that the effect of this input can be found in the measurement of the true output, due to the dynamics. If an attacker is unaware of the watermark, (s)he cannot adequately emulate the system dynamics. Thus, the watermark acts as a cyber-physical nonce, forcing an attacker to generate outputs unique to the given inputs at a chosen time. 

Moving target defence considered the design and analysis of multiple moving target defenses for recognizing and isolating attacks on cyber-physical systems. In particular, it introduces stochastic, time-varying parameters in the control system. The underlying random dynamics of the system limit an attacker's knowledge of the model and inhibit their ability to construct stealthy attack sequences. Moreover, the time-varying nature of the dynamics thwarts adaptive adversaries.
